title-group.article-title: Integrated methodology for evaluation of energy performance of the building enclosures: Part 5—application of the proposed hygrothermal characterization

article-meta.aff: 1College of Mechanical Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai, China
2Mechanical Engineering, Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY, USA

author-notes.corresp: Shui Yu, College of Mechanical Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai 200092, China. Email: yushui19832002@gmail.com

abstract.p: In part 4 of this article series, we have proposed a set of simple tests that is sufficient for estimating material characterization needed for input to advanced hygrothermal models for use in practical applications. Now, we apply this method to the experimental product that was intentionally designed to contain a large fraction of micropores for achieving moisture storage higher than that of traditional Portland cement plaster. The material, called here, eco-wrap or climatic stucco (in contrast to Portland cement plaster), has less cement than natural cement and lime combined and a large fraction of recycled materials.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Moving toward net zero-energy buildings brought us to a necessity of accounting not only for heat but also for air and moisture transfer as they all affect energy efficiency of a building. In part 1 of this article series, we focused on the need for better characterization of building materials if we want to evaluate performance of the whole enclosure system. In this and the subsequent article, we focus on few problems that are not yet solved in the whole system performance analysis in China.

A particular need for this type of work is identified in the mixed climate zone (Shanghai). The common characteristic of humid, mixed climate region is a propensity for the occurrence of condensation and mold growth on the surface of building enclosure components in winter and the increasing costs associated with the long-term operation of air-conditioning devices in summer. Yet because of frequent temperature changes, one cannot use high levels of thermal insulation (Becker, 2010). Therefore, Bomberg and Pazera (2010) decided to expand the capillary active layer approach developed by Häupl et al. (1999) to the hygroscopic region calling it as moisture active layer (MAL) and proposed the use of a dynamic wall that included moisture as a phase change agent.

This approach presents an effective strategy to avoid condensation and to decrease the influence of daily variation in the indoor latent loads. Effectively as shown by Simonson et al. (2004a, 2004b, 2005), this approach can also reduce energy peak loads by 10%–20%. Researchers and industries in China are pursuing this approach even though the first step of this research involves the analysis of the climatic stucco proposed for exterior thermal insulation systems. The climatic stucco discussed in this article (Yu et al., 2012) is one of the required new components for these thermal insulation systems. This article specifically addresses the hygrothermal (HT) characteristics of the climatic stucco and forms a step in the work of CIB W40 Task Group by demonstrating that material characteristics can be measured without measuring the moisture distribution profiles in materials.

sec.title: Geometrical characterization of the material
sec.p: When the building materials are subject to high latent loads in the building interior, the capability to maintain the balance between wetting and drying processes becomes important, and the attention is focused on the characterization of materials. For many years, the geometrical characterization of porous media was considered to be an important step in this process. When considering material structure at a macroscopic level, the critical parameters/properties are mean pore size and pore size distribution. Out of several methods that can be used to determine these properties, we will discuss one with a view to assessing its capability for discrimination of material variability.

sec.title: Pore size distribution
sec.p: ASAP 2020 equipment is used to test the porosity of materials using the volumetric test gas adsorption. Figure 1 shows the principle of the test equipment.

caption.p: The operating principle of ASAP 2020 instrument: (a) instrument and (b) principle.

sec.p: To calculate the surface area of eco-stucco, we used the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) multilayer adsorption theory. A total surface area Stotal and a specific surface area S are derived from the following equation

where vm is the volume in units of the molar volume of the adsorbed gas, N is Avogadro’s number, and s is the adsorption cross section of the adsorbing species. Here, BET surface area of eco-stucco is 4.3665 m2/g. Figure 2 shows the pore size distribution and cumulative pore volume of eco-stucco measured using the ASAP 2020 equipment. One may observe two peaks in the distribution of pore size (incremental pore volume), one peak is found around 300 Å (3 × 10−8 m) and the other around 950 Å, that is, in the middle and at the end of the micropore region.

caption.p: The pore size distribution and cumulative volume of eco-stucco measured using ASAP 2020 equipment.
DFT: density functional theory.

sec.title: Characterization of surface area
sec.p: A fractal has been defined as “a rough or fragmented geometric shape that can be split into parts, each of which is (at least approximately) a reduced-size copy of the whole,” a property called “self-similarity” (Mandelbrot, 1982). Practically, the box-counting dimension is widely used, partly due to their ease of implementation.
A set of F contained in Rn is as follows: for any δ > 0, let Nδ(F) be the minimum number of n-dimensional cubes of side length δ needed to cover F. If there is a number DB so that
where DB is the box-counting fractal dimension, N is the total grid number, and c is the intercept.

At present, there is no relation between N(δ) and pore size distribution; N(δ) is the total grid number depending on variable δ. Figure 3 shows the scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of specimens. The box-counting fractal dimension is the slope of fitting line shown in Figures 4 and 5.The pore area fraction is shown in Table 1.

caption.p: SEM images of eco-stucco on different surfaces with the magnification 2000 and its gray photo representation: (a) SEM of top surface of eco-stucco+, (b) gray photo of top surface of eco-stucco+, (c) SEM of bottom surface of eco-stucco−, and (d) gray photo of bottom surface of eco-stucco−.
SEM: scanning electron microscope.
Fitting line of box-counting dimension on top surface of eco-stucco.
Fitting line of box-counting dimension on bottom surface of eco-stucco.
The area fraction of eco-stucco (top and bottom sections)

sec.title: Discussion on the example of the geometrical characterization
sec.p: The above section illustrates the capability of geometrical material characterization to quantify the differences between top and bottom sections of the test specimen. It is an important issue in the analysis of uncertainty of the measured material characteristics. The geometrical characterization showed that the objective of the eco-stucco design (increase of hygroscopic behavior of this material) was satisfied. Yet we did not find any general methods of correlation between the geometrical characterization of porous media and the transport characteristics (Carmeliet and Roels, 2001). For this reason, we must focus on direct methods of measuring or estimation of HT characteristics of the material. We will, therefore, review the methods of measuring/estimating moisture fixation and moisture transport characteristics.

sec.title: Moisture fixation (moisture retention curves)
sec.p: In the following section, we use a combination of measurements and estimation. The first element of material characterization is invariably the determination of moisture equilibrium as a function of relative humidity (RH), under wetting and drying processes, a so-called sorption isotherm. The sorption isotherms are the initial part of the moisture retention curves. The second part of the moisture retention curves can be measured with pressure plates. Yet the pressure plates for use with solid materials must be constructed in such a manner that hydraulic contact between the test specimen and the pressure plate is interrupted without changing the air pressure (Bomberg, 1974). Testing solid materials with the equipment designed for soils where pressure is modified before the specimen is removed gives uncertain results (Bomberg and Pazera, 2010). We therefore follow the practice of estimating moisture retention curves by extending the sorption and desorption isotherms to the measured capillary moisture content (MC).

sec.title: Isothermal sorption
sec.p: The saturated salt solutions have the corresponding RH levels at a room temperature, namely, 97.3% by K2SO4, 94.0% by KNO3, 84.3% by KCl, 75.3% by NaCl, 53.49% by Mg(NO3)2, and 32.9% by MgCl. In this work, we used the difference in mass of less than 0.1% between two nonconsecutive weightings over a minimum period of 10 days as the criterion for establishing the equilibrium MC. For the specimen to be assumed as oven dry, the weight loss between three nonconsecutive measurements performed within 24 h at temperature slightly above 100°C has to be less than 0.1%.
MC could be calculated by equation (6), w (kg/kg), using the mean values of the mass of tested specimens at each test condition.
where m is the mean mass of specimens at equilibrium and m0 is the mass of the dry specimens.

Both the adsorption and desorption isotherms have been determined and plotted in Figure 6. The difference between equilibrium MC of adsorption and desorption loop of the sorption isotherm characterizes the effect of capillary hysteresis. Figure 6 shows the adsorption and desorption curves for eco-stucco specimen and the fitting curve calculated with the empirical model (equation (5), see Richards et al., 1992).
where a, b, and c are the constant coefficients obtained from fitting the equation to experimental data.

caption.p: The isothermal sorption curves of eco-stucco specimens.

sec.p: We will discuss the estimation of the moisture retention curves in the region above 98% following the discussion on variability in capillary MC.

sec.title: Moisture transport coefficients
sec.p: When the capillary condensation develops in micropores of the material, the liquid phase in the form of adsorbed and absorbed water influences the rate of the moisture transport. Even though the prevailing mode of the transport is still the vapor phase flow, it is not anymore a pure diffusion. Hence, let us discuss, for simplicity, about moisture transport in the vapor phase. Typically, for hydrofilling porous materials, the presence of capillary water increases the rate of moisture transport in the upper part of the hygroscopic range.

sec.title: Water transport in the vapor phase (water vapor permeability)
sec.p: Water vapor permeability (WVP) is the coefficient used to describe the vapor diffusion process. In the low RH range, before capillary condensation modifies the rate of WV transport (that for typical construction materials occurs in the range of above 50% RH), the total moisture flow may be ascribed to WV diffusion (equation (6))

The eco-stucco contains both water-retaining and hydrophobic polymers, and the character of the moisture transport in the hygroscopic range cannot be predicted without experimental work. Therefore, we used a new approach denoted as “multilayer test” that involves simultaneous exposure of several material layers each separated by an air gap (Pazera, 2007, 2011; Pazera and Salonvaara, 2012).

Figure 7 shows the results of multilayer, dry cup and wet cup test methods. It appears that the drop of partial pressure of WV measured on the air layer is smaller than the one used in the simulations. This is not surprising because the RH sensors measure an average RH at some distance from the surface, while the simulation involves resistance of the air gap and addresses the full air gap. Figure 8 shows the dependence of WVP on partial pressure of WV, and since this is an isothermal test, it can be presented in the form of RH. The results show agreement between different test methods.

caption.p: Measured and simulated relative humidity distributions in two series of tests.

WVP versus mean RH of the eco-stucco specimens and the fitting WVP dependence on RH. Moisture flux in the first series of measurements was 0.00111 g/(m2·s) and in the second 0.00125 g/(m2·s). In the first series of measurements, dry and wet cup tests were also performed.
WVP: water vapor permeability; RH: relative humidity.

sec.title: Free water intake and drying experiments
sec.p: Figure 9 shows the measured cumulative free water intake measured on experimental eco-stucco samples against the approximation obtained by adjusting the input to the simulation to agree with the measurements—a “fitted simulated curve.” The density of the tested eco-stucco specimen is 1400 kg/m3. The specimen is assumed to have reached its capillary saturation when weight variation is less than 0.1% of its weight over required period of time. For eco-stucco, capillary saturation varied from 220 to 280 kg/m3 with the average MC wcap at 254 kg/m3.

caption.p: Cumulative water intake per unit of surface area (kg/m2) as a function of square root of time (s1/2). Measurements and fitted “calculations” on experimental eco-stucco.

sec.p: Figure 9 shows a significant variation of capillary saturation values obtained on different specimens. It can be explained by the fact that eco-stucco included several recycled materials and that samples were prepared by hand using different amounts of water. Incidentally, the variations of A-coefficient shown in Figure 10 are of similar magnitude to those observed on actual stucco samples taken from several buildings located in Pacific coastal area (private communication with Dr Achilles Karagiozis), indicating that the contribution of workmanship on building site could have been as significant as the variation in the material itself.

caption.p: Moisture content of eco-stucco versus square root of time for water uptake and drying process.

sec.p: The comparison of the water absorption curves is interesting for a number of reasons. In Figure 3, we have shown the differences between top and bottom surfaces of the specimen, and the subsequent discussion about geometrical characterization proved that there are real differences in the structure of the material. Looking at Figure 9 remind us about the existence of correlation between A-coefficient and capillary saturation values that was highlighted in other research (Koronthalyova and Matiasovsky, 2001, 2003).

At this moment, we need to remind the reader that when the eco-stucco specimens reach their maximum MC attainable under free water intake, that is, when free water ingress is stopped because of the air entrapment, the difference between atmospheric air and water pressure is close to zero, and this means that the average capillary suction of the pore water is close to zero. Of course, the specimen is not fully saturated and dissolution or removal of air entrapped in the pore system can increase the water content in the specimen, but in our macroscopic model, we may assume that the thermodynamic equilibrium obtained at this stage represents the end of the free water ingress into the porous material. Figure 10 shows the relation between MC of eco-stucco and square root of time during both the water uptake and drying process.

sec.title: Transport coefficients for vapor and liquid phases
sec.p: The gradient of partial pressure of WV constitutes the driving potential for the vapor phase transport (equation (8)). The transport coefficient for WV in equation (9) is replaced by the ratio of the diffusion of WV in still air to vapor resistance factor (μ). Under isothermal conditions, a gradient of vapor pressure can be replaced by a gradient of capillary pressure using the so-called Kelvin law, see equation (8).

where Dv, air(T) is the vapor diffusivity/permeability in free air (m2/s), f(θg) is the function of volume fraction of gas phase (calculated from MC), typically f(θg) = θg, θg is the volume fraction of gas phase, δ is the WVP determined by dry/wet cups or multilayer test method.
Since we use a HT model based on moisture potential, in equation (9) we use logarithmic scale of the transport coefficients for vapor and liquid phases (see Figure 11).

caption.p: Vapor phase conductivity coefficient (i.e. related to the driving potential) that can be input to hygrothermal models based on measurements presented in Figure 6 (sorption isotherm) and Figure 8 (water vapor permeability).

sec.p: The degree of saturation used in Figure 11 represents one of the few cases shown in Figure 10. In Figure 12, using individual measurements of capillary saturation as shown in Figures 6 and 9, we calculated four different curves of liquid conductivity, each representing measurements on one specimen. Looking at Figure 12, we may see small differences between specimens 3 and 4, while curves for specimens 1, 2, and 4 appear to be similar but shifted on the potential scale.

caption.p: Logarithm of Kl versus an average degree of capillary saturation for four tested eco-stucco specimens during wetting and drying processes.

sec.p: We must now explain why in Figures 11 and 12 we have switched from MC to the degree of capillary moisture saturation. As discussed in part 4 of this article series, we have dealt with two types of hysteresis; capillary hysteresis and air entrapment hysteresis (i.e. different fractions of air in the pore water/air mixture filling the whole volume of the open pore space). The field of capillary moisture must, therefore, be separated from the oversaturated capillary moisture, and the capillary saturation as displayed in Figure 9 constitutes the end of free capillary flows. There is a large variation in the capillary MC measured for this material, and therefore, we must normalize the results of individual measurements by using equation (10)

We postulated that the capillary saturation measured for each of the specimens represent a measure of the specimen structure variation from the average and normalize all measured data to the degree of effective saturation. Bomberg (1974) introduced a correction for drying process that starts in the region between w98 and wcap. Yet in this project, all drying tests were started at the capillary saturation, so we do not need to discuss any hysteretic correction to the concept of effective degree of saturation.

A logistic model is used to fit the calculated curves, where A2 is the maximum value of Log Kl. When Se is larger than 0.50, Log Kl is almost equal to A2. The maximum value of Log Kl is 11.598 and 13.92 for wetting and drying processes, respectively
Normalized MCs using equation (10) and individual values of capillary MC are shown for wetting and drying processes in Figure 13.

caption.p: Degree of capillary saturation for eco-stucco versus square root of time for water uptake and drying process.

sec.p: Figure 13 represents real variability of material characteristics for the eco-stucco when corrected for differences in the free water ingress as expressed by the degree of capillary saturation.

sec.title: Material characteristics based on degree of capillary saturation
sec.p: Each specimen tested for wetting and drying processes has wcap measured, and moisture characteristics are expressed below in relation to the degree of capillary saturation.

Liquid water transport could be calculated by equation (14), assuming all other flows, namely, diffusive liquid water flow, dispersive liquid water, and dispersive WV flow, are negligible. Equation 14 could be written as the form of equation (16), combining equation (15) used to describe the capillary pressure and the relationship between MC and RH
where a, b, and c are the constants, Rv = R/Mwater is the ideal gas constant for water 461.92 m3·Pa/(K·kg), and ϕ is the RH (%).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Figure 14 shows the moisture retention curves. The presence of capillary hysteresis is visible in the Se ranging from 0 to about 0.45 and above 0.85. There is not enough experimental data to comment on the observed lack of the hysteretic effect in the Se ranging between 0.45 and 0.85.

caption.p: Moisture retention curve for eco-stucco (using an average of four individual curves, an average is represented as curve 1 for wetting process and curve 2 for drying process).

sec.p: A similar pattern is shown in Figure 15, which shows drying and wetting loops as nearly identical, indicating that using capillary saturation instead of MC reduces the effects of variability in material structure allowing the use of simplified approach to material characterization, even though Figure 16 shows two clearly different liquid conductivity curves, one for wetting process and one for drying process.

caption.p: Water vapor conductivity curve for the eco-stucco tested in this project (curve 1 for wetting process and curve 2 for drying process). Kv means water vapor conductivity, and it is calculated from isothermal sorption experiment, in fact, when RH is 85%, Se is about 0.3, so here, the maximum value of Se is 0.5.
RH: relative humidity.

Liquid water vapor conductivity curve for eco-stucco using an average of measured values and average of the measured capillary saturation values. Wetting process is represented by curve 0, and drying process is represented by curve 1.

sec.title: Check of the reliability of material characteristics
sec.p: As discussed elsewhere (Bomberg and Pazera, 2010), all simplified methods of material characterization must be verified with an independent process where measurements are compared to calculation that uses the previously determined material functions. The use of heat flow measurements on sealed, wet specimen inserted in a heat flow meter is one such test method. This test method is used here with an extra twist. Transient heat flux and temperatures on both surfaces of the specimen were recorded.

Table 2 shows the basic information of moist eco-stucco specimen used for verification test heat flux through the specimen, and its surface temperature was measured in a sequence of transient and steady temperatures as shown in Figure 17. Three different settings of top and bottom temperatures were used. When the whole system reaches the quasi-steady state under certain temperature gradient (phase 1), one reverses the specimen orientation, placing the cold surface on the hot plate and vice versa (phase 2).

caption.p: The description of the eco-stucco specimen

Surface temperatures, (1) top and (2) bottom, on the sealed eco-stucco specimen with moisture content 7.07% by weight. When reversing the specimen, one needs time to weight the specimen, install temperature and heat flux sensors on the surface, and set the equipment before start of the test.

sec.p: Finally, Figure 18 shows heat fluxes (1) measured and (2) calculated for the sealed specimen of eco-stucco containing 7.07% moisture by weight and surface temperatures as shown in Figure 17. The agreement between measured and calculated using CHAMPS computer code is sufficient.

caption.p: Heat flux on the two surfaces of moist eco-stucco, with MC = 7.07% by experiment and simulation (curve 1 is the measured heat flux and curve 2 is simulated).
MC: moisture content.

ack.p: Detailed discussions with Profs Nathan Mendes and Shuichi Hokoi are acknowledged and appreciated.
